subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{wikipedia|lang=ja|ハス|蓮}} {{wikipedia|Nelumbo nucifera}} [[File:Mukuge.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|蓮}} (''hachisu''): '''''[[Hibiscus syriacus]]''''': the '''[[rose of Sharon]]''', '''[[rose mallow]]''', or '''{{vern|St. Joseph's rod}}'''.]] [[File:Sacred_lotus_Nelumbo_nucifera.jpg|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|蓮}} (''hachisu'', ''hasu'', ''ren''): '''''[[Nelumbo nucifera]]''''': the '''[[lotus]] [[flower]] and [[plant]]'''.]]
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|はちす}} Originally a compound of {{compound|ja|sort=はちす|蜂|tr1=hachi|t1=bee|巣|tr2=su|t2=nest, hive}}, literally “[[beehive]], [[honeycomb]]”, from the way the [[lotus]] [[seed]] resembles a [[honeycomb]].{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}{{R:Daijirin}}

subSections.title: Noun
Proper noun
Etymology 2
Usage notes
subSections.text: The reading ''hasu'' appears to be more common for the {{m|en|lotus}} meaning in modern Japanese.

subSections.title: Etymology 3
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=o|れん}}
From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=れん}} {{m|zh|蓮|tr=len||lotus fruit}}. Compare modern {{etyl|cmn|-}} reading ''lián''.

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: The ''ren'' reading is seldom used on its own. It is most often used in compounds.

subSections.title: Derived terms
